questions.question_text:
When reviewing the system logs, the cybersecurity analyst noticed a suspicious log entry: wmic /node: HRDepartment1 computersystem get username
Which of the following combinations describes what occurred, and what action should be taken in this situation?

choices.B: A rogue user has queried for the administrator logged into the system. Attempt to determine who executed the command.
choices.C: A rogue user has queried for the administrator logged into the system. Disable local access to use cmd prompt.
choices.D: A rogue user has queried for users logged into in remotely. Attempt to determine who executed the command.
choices.A: A rogue user has queried for users logged in remotely. Disable local access to network shares.

discussion.content: Poor wording for the answer. I think letter D wants to say that a rogue user has remotely queried for user logged in.

questions.question_text: A security analyst is creating baseline system images to remediate vulnerabilities found in different operating systems. Each image needs to be scanned before it is deployed. The security analyst must ensure the configurations match industry standard benchmarks and the process can be repeated frequently. Which of the following vulnerability options would BEST create the process requirements?

choices.A: Utilizing an operating system SCAP plugin

discussion.content: This question was in the exam :)

I think the answer is D actually, but I'm not 100% sure. I'll try to explain my logic here:
A. The incident response team should not rely on Legal for something that should be part of a procedure/policy.
B. Too vague to be correct imho.
C. This is partially correct. You would rely on Legal to help you determine when to involve Law Enforcement.
D. I think this is the right answer because it's exactly what Legal would be able to help the incident response team with. PII data got "lost" (accidental or not)? Legal can tell us exactly what our duties are (legally speaking) on notifying affected parties (be it customers, vendors whatever). An incident is a criminal act? Legal can tell us exactly how we can approach law enforcements and what details we can share with law enforcements.
I think the answer should be D too.
answer is A majority of the answers are correct. pls read well before you answer. in Bcms some of these answers are there in the book.
Not D... To predetermine? The incident is in progress... So they need to get together...Touch base and ensure everyone is on the same page...
i think the answer should be D. don't really know why is A . but it's what it's

I went with B. I would agree that existing policies should dictate who would do what. If you're not reviewing policies and procedures on a regular basis, it's conceivable that soemone somewhere would forget who does what. Hence, B would seem to be the right answer.

comments.content: Agree, possibly its stated in policy that this should happen but the reason for the meeting would be to everyone knows what to do etc

choices.D: To predetermine what details should or should not be shared with internal or external parties in the event of an incident
choices.C: To identify which group will communicate details to law enforcement in the event of a security incident
choices.B: To ensure all parties know their roles and effective lines of communication are established
choices.A: To comply with existing organization policies and procedures on interacting with internal and external parties

questions.question_text: Which of the following describes why it is important for an organization's incident response team and legal department to meet and discuss communication processes during the incident response process?

discussion.content: This should be A and B, assuming this is a company workstation.

comments.content: It doesn't mention that it's a company workstation. And even if it is, it's not inconceivable for companies to work on movie clips. Deleting the entire directory is an over the top response. Defragmenting reduces disk usage without potentially deleting crucial data

discussion.content: A and B IMHO. Defrag will not work if you have no space on HDD and just disabling the service will not increase disk space.
A & B are the obvious solutions to the problem

This is simple, Read the question
So A and B.
Defragmentation is a technique to reduce the disk space, but in this case if we dont perform both above A and B, it will lead again to make High Disk Space

comments.content: It's a desktop workstation. How often do you take your desktop into work with you?
It just says technician. It does not mention it to be a security analyst or the likes of it.

discussion.content: It doesn't say anything about it being a company computer, nor does it say anything about the service being unwanted. What would the answer be if this was a legitimate service?
Agreed, A and B. Once the movie directory is deleted, then maybe do the defrag.
